If you're experiencing issues with setting up Gmail's 2-step verification, there are a few things you can try to resolve the problem:

Double-check your phone number: Ensure that you have entered your phone number correctly during the setup process. Verify that the country code and phone number are accurate, and check for any typos.

Check your network connection: Make sure you have a stable and reliable internet connection. A weak or intermittent connection may cause issues with receiving the verification code.

Request a new verification code: If you haven't received the verification code, you can click on the option to request a new code. If Thunderbird is not displaying clickable hyperlinks, you can try the following troubleshooting steps:

Check HTML message format: Ensure that the email you're viewing is in HTML format and not plain text. Thunderbird may not display clickable hyperlinks in plain text mode. You can switch between HTML and plain text views by going to the "View" menu and selecting "Message Body As" > "Original HTML" or "Simple HTML."

Verify Thunderbird settings: Check your Thunderbird settings to make sure hyperlinks are enabled. To do this, go to Thunderbird's main menu, select "Tools," and choose "Options" (or "Preferences" on macOS). In the Options/Preferences window, select the "Display" tab and make sure the "Allow remote content in messages" option is checked. This allows Thunderbird to display hyperlinks correctly.

Disable add-ons or extensions: Certain add-ons or extensions in Thunderbird can interfere with the display of hyperlinks. Try disabling any add-ons or extensions you have installed and see if the issue persists. To disable add-ons, go to the main menu, select "Tools," and choose "Add-ons." Disable any extensions and restart Thunderbird.

Update Thunderbird: Make sure you have the latest version of Thunderbird installed. Outdated versions may have bugs or compatibility issues that could affect the display of hyperlinks. You can check for updates by going to the main menu, selecting "Help," and choosing "About Thunderbird." If an update is available, follow the prompts to install it.

Check antivirus or firewall settings: Some antivirus programs or firewall settings can interfere with Thunderbird's ability to display hyperlinks. Temporarily disable any antivirus software or adjust firewall settings and see if that resolves the issue.

If you're experiencing issues with sending outgoing mail in Thunderbird, here are some troubleshooting steps you can try:

Check SMTP server settings: Verify that the SMTP server settings in Thunderbird are configured correctly. To do this, go to Thunderbird's main menu, select "Tools," and choose "Account Settings." In the Account Settings window, select the email account experiencing the issue and click on the "Server Settings" category. Ensure that the SMTP server hostname, port number, and connection security settings match the requirements of your email provider. If you're unsure about the correct settings, you can check with your email provider or consult their support documentation.

Check authentication settings: Confirm that the correct authentication method is selected for the SMTP server. In the same "Server Settings" section as mentioned above, check the "Authentication method" dropdown menu. Depending on your email provider, you may need to use options like "Password, Normal," "OAuth2," or "TLS Certificate" for authentication. Again, referring to your email provider's instructions can help determine the appropriate authentication method to use.

The html signature may be the cause but it would depend upon what you had in the signature html file. The problem would also disappear if you stopped using the signature.

How did you create the signature html file ? Did you do this:

  • Open a new Write message window.
  • Completely clear all contents.
  • Press Enter/Return twice to move a little down - this makes it easier to compose emails and looks more professional. It also will set the first lines to use the default settings.
  • Use a table if you need to control the exact placement of signature contents.
  • Then enter data for signature.
  • If you want the actual text of signature to be different eg: bold or different colour, then only highlight that text before choosing any formatting options.
  • File > Save as > File
  • Choose a suitable location - In my computer User Account I have afolder called 'Signatures' and it contains all my signature html files and also any images etc used in signatures, so they are all in one location.
  • Give file suitable name eg: formal-sig
  • save as html file
  • Close the Write window.

In Account Settings

  • select name of account
  • select checkbox 'Attach the signature from a file instead'
  • Click on 'Choose'
  • locate and select the html signature file you just created
  • click on Open

click on 'Write' to see signature.
